user.biography: Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, and the tranquility of the High Sierra.

node.text:
Throughout human history, songs have served as a catalyst for connection. Songs have continuously been used to celebrate one’s culture, bring people together and bring about the emotions that only music can surface. While we may be surrounded by human song on our day-to-day basis, we may also encounter them through the natural world around us. 

As a Global Important Bird Area, Yosemite is enriched by birdsongs throughout the park. Although birdsongs may sound like beautiful melodies for us, they can be a means to defend and impress. Many birds are territorial, meaning that they lay claim to specific areas. Songs allow them to identify these regions as their own and are often used to defend this space. In other circumstances, male birds use songs to attract females. Melodies give these birds a chance to show off and impress potential mates. Being mindful of the distinctive soundscapes around us can help us differentiate and identify birds we encounter anywhere in the world. 

With 262 different species documented inside the park, there are endless opportunities to enjoy birding in Yosemite. Just a stroll through the park can introduce you to a whole new world of sound and flight right above your head. For more information on birds and birdwatching in Yosemite, please visit https://www.nps.gov/yose/planyourvisit/birdwatching.htm. 

[Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SbkqNiiwHXg]

node.text:
Today marks the 25th anniversary of the 1996 Happy Isles rockfall.  At 6:52 pm on July 10, 1996, two blocks with a combined volume of about 30,000 cubic meters and weighing about 90,000 tons broke loose from high on the southeast part of Glacier Point, hitting the valley floor near Happy Isles. In terms of volume, this equates to about 2000 SUVs dropping onto the valley floor at the same time. The impacts of the blocks generated an airblast with wind speeds up to 280 miles per hour, comparable to that of a Category 5 hurricane or a F5 tornado on the Fujita Scale. 

The airblast uprooted and snapped about one thousand trees, which damaged buildings and caused one fatality and several serious injuries.  Following the airblast, a dense cloud of pulverized rock blanketed the area with coarse sand and dust.  Dust rose rapidly into the air and plunged the Happy Isles area into darkness for several minutes.  Search and rescue personnel spent the next several days searching for victims in extremely challenging conditions but fortunately discovered no further casualities. 

Although tragic, this event would have been much more consequential if the rockfall had occurred just a few hours earlier.  Nevertheless, the 1996 Happy Isles rockfalls remains one of the most devastating rockfalls in Yosemite’s history.

[Video: Helicopter footage showing the destruction of the rockslide opens the video showing hundreds of downed trees and rocks on the valley floor. On-the-scene footage of the destruction at Happy Isles is then shown. Emergency search and rescue teams as well as search dogs scour the rubble searching for survivors and clearing the debris. Footage of destroyed building exteriors and interiors are also featured.]

node.title: Aftermath of the 1996 Happy Isles Rockfall

node.text:
“He is the mountain streams’ own darling, the humming-bird of blooming waters, loving rocky ripple-slopes and sheets of foam as a bee loves flowers, as a lark loves sunshine and meadows. Among all the mountain birds, none has cheered me so much in my lonely wanderings, —none so unfailingly. For both in winter and summer he sings, sweetly, cheerily, independent alike of sunshine and of love, requiring no other inspiration than the stream on which he dwells”. – John Muir

The muse of Mr. Muir’s prose is none other than the Ouzel, or American dipper (Cinclus mexicanus). Looking much like a dipping, wading, swimming, and occasionally flying, cobble with bluish-gray feathers, dippers are found almost exclusively along the rivers and streams in which they live. They feed on larval stage water insects and can be seen moving leaves and rocks under the water in search of a meal. Nests are built along the streams on rocky, protected, areas above flood lines. Dippers need clear, unpolluted waters and, as such, are considered an indicator species of water quality. While they remain in much of their original habitat range, they have been extirpated from streams that became too polluted for them to survive. 

Very often seen from the banks and bridges in Yosemite, their movements and behaviors can be mesmerizing to watch. Dippers frequently make short chirps, however their melodic songs can brighten the even dreariest of winter days.
#Yosemite #NationalPark #Ouzel #AmericanDipper #Cinclus

node.text:
Join Ranger Kate and her special canine assistants for some pollinator science.
Pollinators come in all shapes and sizes! So do your household pets. You can try this experiment at home with your own pet to see how effective they are as pollinators!
Step 1: Find a few jars or cups of different shapes and sizes.
Step 2: Give them some fancy paper petals or leaves to 
look like flowers!
Step 3:  Perhaps create some paper wings or antennae 
to adorn your favorite pet…
Step 4:  Get a few small treats for your pets to serve as 
their ‘nectar reward’ inside the flower.
Step 5: Test your pet-pollinator!
How many jars did they get a reward from?  Why? 
Did they have any specific technique? 
Please share your results in the comments! 
BONUS if you can research and find out what pollinator in nature your pet is the most like!
Remember- some pollinators are more effective than others, but it’s still important that they are here on this planet doing their job.
Even if your pet-pollinator isn’t very ‘effective,’ what matters most is that they are very loved!

node.title: Pollinator Science with Ranger Kate & Friends

node.text:
We are reposting our video of Shelton Johnson discussing hidden histories for African American History Month. A story that has become uncovered can become buried simply by the steady stream of newer stories, so it seems pertinent to reinforce this one. What other underrepresented stories are out there that we should recover and amplify?
#AfricanAmericanHistoryMonth

node.title: Ranger Shelton Johnson Speaks about African American History Month 2021

node.text:
On a recent winter afternoon, we watch two female common mergansers diving in the Merced River, searching the river bottom rocks for an aquatic critter for lunch.

These large ducks, with a distinctive pointed orange bill, can be found in Yosemite Valley all year. In early summer you might catch a mother herding her ducklings along the riverbank scooting from cove to cove on the Merced River.

node.title: Mergansers hunting in the Merced River

node.text: Join Ranger Alex in another conversation with one of Yosemite's misunderstood animals.

node.title: Misunderstood Animals with Ranger Alex: Episode Bat

node.accessibility_caption: Purple flowers in the foreground contrast the red alpine mountains in the background. A blue sky and clouds are overhead.

node.text:
Yosemite is home to a vast number of wildflower species and plant communities. Colorful pockets of flora bloom annually throughout the park, bringing with them the smells, hues, and excitement of the warming season. Wildflowers can be spotted at all elevations, from the shores of the low Merced River Canyon to the alpine meadows of Mono Pass. Yosemite's unique location within the Sierra Nevada makes way for over 1,450 different species to flourish, including a number of flowers that cannot be found anywhere else in the world. 

Due to the rainy weather we have been experiencing over these past few weeks, wildflowers have continued to bloom in Yosemite’s higher elevations. A visit to the high country at this time of year might grant you a unique glimpse of the brilliant flowers that call Yosemite home. 

Wildflowers are a stark reminder of the ephemerality of nature. When in Yosemite, please be mindful to stay on designated trails to avoid trampling the park’s flowers.

node.accessibility_caption: A tall ponderosa pine standing in the Indian Village.

node.text:
Tree identification can sometimes be a puzzling task. Naturalists around the park tend to rely on a variety of sensory characteristics to determine different tree species using a range of techniques. Examining needles, leaves, bark, and cones, feeling a tree’s texture, and even smelling the tree itself are all useful in the identification process. 

One of Yosemite’s most recognizable tree species is the ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa). Known as the most widely distributed pine species in North America, ponderosas can be found throughout the Sierra Nevada. These trees can grow to stunning heights of over 200 feet with trunks reaching up to four feet across. Ponderosas needles occur in bunches of three ranging from five to ten inches long and are distinctively bright green, while their cones have prickly  ends pointing outward towards the sky. Depending on who you ask, these trees may even smell of turpentine.

Maybe the most popular way to identify a ponderosa is to look at its bark! Ever been frustrated by a difficult puzzle? Ponderosa bark characteristically has deep furrows on its surface, dividing the bark into easily recognizable puzzle-like pieces. When the outer bark chips away, its remnants mirror the jigsaw shapes that are reminiscent of many of our childhoods. 

The use of our senses is essential when it comes to giving names to species around us. What other species have you identified before?

node.accessibility_caption: A tall ponderosa pine standing in the Indian Village.
A close-up image of the ponderosa bark that highlights the jigsaw pattern of the bark.
A hand with a watch on the wrist holds up a ponderosa pine cone. Ponderosa bark is in the background.
Black and white image of three individuals standing beneath the Dead Giant tunnel tree.

node.text:
A giant sequoia tree is not the only historic feature you might find in the Tuolumne Grove. Serving as the paved walkway into the grove, the Old Big Oak Flat Road was one of the earliest stage roads that led to the valley. The road was completed in 1874 after years of grueling construction and was open to the public until the 1940s. 

Archeological evidence shows that American Indians have occupied the areas around the road for at least 6,000 years. Following the California Gold Rush in the 19th century, many miners turned to the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, exploring and reinforcing existing trails in the area. The construction of the Old Big Oak Flat Road along the miner’s routes served as a more accessible means to venture through the winding mountains in stages, speeding up travel time. The road had to be realigned, reconstructed, and arduously maintained throughout the years due to its consistent use. 

Although the road has been closed to vehicles for a few decades, you can still see the remains of this significant route on your hike to the grove. A tunnel was gouged into a fire-scarred sequoia in 1878 to entice enthusiastic visitors. Stage riding tourists experienced the unique opportunity to drive through a fully grown sequoia tree on their way into the park. Today, you are still able to walk beneath the tree’s rings on your hike, experiencing the same delight that weary travelers felt more than a century ago.

node.accessibility_caption: A large yellow crane dumping dirt into a white truck in a meadow. The royal arches and Half Dome are in the background.

node.text:
Have you seen heavy equipment in Ahwahnee Meadow lately? We are restoring wetland habitat in the meadow as part of the implementation of the Merced Wild and Scenic River Management Plan.

Historical impacts to the meadow included agricultural activities (tilling, seeding, and grazing), construction of housing that confines flows from the Indian Creek alluvial fan, and presence of roads and bike paths. Addition of imported soil to act as fill, potentially to control mosquitoes in the 1930s, also changed this area. People affected the natural topography, hydrology, and plant communities, which resulted in loss of wetland habitat, and higher, drier areas dominated by invasive species.

We are removing fill, recontouring the area to historical meadow elevations, revegetating the area with locally sourced native meadow seed mix, and removing invasive plants. These actions will restore hydrological connectivity to existing wetland habitat in the meadow, improve habitat quality for flora and fauna, and enhance the meadow’s resiliency to drought and climate change. To evaluate restoration success, we will monitor the project area after the project is complete to assess whether species composition and abundance has changed and if hydrology has improved.

We have learned lessons from our past mistakes and are taking action to remedy them. For this reason, be aware that heavy equipment is necessary to carry out this work. Please be cautious when passing by this area and stay on the paved paths. Thank you to the Vegetation and Ecological Restoration crew for all of their incredible work!

node.accessibility_caption: A large yellow crane dumping dirt into a white truck in a meadow. The royal arches and Half Dome are in the background.
Four restoration crew members in yellow vests standing in the meadow along the fence. One is digging into the dirt with a shovel, while another is holding wires.
A restoration crew member smiles into the camera. She is crouching in the green meadow and has an orange backpack.
A smiling restoration crew member in an orange vest and yellow hard hat sprays water through a hose in the meadow. A crane and Half Dome are in the background.
A yellow crane operated by a restoration crew member digging up dirt in the meadow.
A restoration crew member in a green vest and yellow hard hat digging into the meadow. Half Dome is in the background.
A yellow crane operated by a restoration crew member digs into the green vegetation of the meadow, while another crew member sprays water on the area with a hose.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: A ranger stands in front of an ambulance in the foreground. A helicopter stationed on the ground is in the background.

node.text:
We are once again asking you be our partner in recreating responsibly. Intensive care units in our region are very busy. While Yosemite's ambulance service is functioning normally, hospital care could be delayed if you are in an accident or become ill. So, err on the side of caution in every decision you make. Now is not the time to take risks and push your limits while recreating in the park. Entering a closed area or engaging in a high-risk activity could lead to a serious accident; the consequences of that action could be dire for both the injured party and rescuers alike.

Please #RecreateResponsibly by planning and preparing thoroughly for your outdoor activities in the park:
 -Stay on the trail!
 -Bring plenty of water and food, and remember to take breaks in shade throughout the day. Highs in Yosemite Valley are forecast to be around 100°F.
 -Pack multiple sources of light (a headlamp or flashlight in addition to your cell phone).
 -Plan your route: study a map ahead of time and pay attention to where you are along your journey. Bring and refer frequently to a map. If there is a map at the trailhead, take a photo of it with your smartphone.
 -Respect Your Limits - When hiking, be honest about your progress throughout the day. You may have to turn around earlier than planned to avoid rushing down the trail as it becomes dark. The majority of injuries occur on the way downhill or during the second half of the journey, so please pace yourself and take extra care.
 -Pay attention to how you and everyone else in your group is feeling. Do not “push through” any pain or discomfort; instead, take a moment to rest and make an honest assessment about whether the group should continue or turn back.
 -If you are recreating alone, let someone know your planned itinerary and ensure they will contact us if you are overdue.

Additionally, please remember to wear a mask indoors (regardless of vaccination status), and outdoors when social distancing isn't possible, Please stay home if you are feeling sick.

node.accessibility_caption: A black oak with a broken branch drooping towards the sidewalk. There is yellow caution tape in front of it.

node.text:
For many, sitting beneath an oak can be an act of reprieve, solitude, and tranquility. An array of slender branches and colorful leaves can provide a cool haven during the hot summer months as one settles into a comfortable spot beneath the seemingly protective limbs of a large tree. Although this may sound like a serene escape, resting beneath an oak can inadvertently place you into a dangerous situation. 

The fallen branch that you see here is a recent example of summer branch drop syndrome. Summer branch drop (SBD) is a common seasonal occurrence when a seemingly healthy tree suddenly loses a limb oftentimes without warning. These limb drops typically happens during the summer when heat begins to creep into the park and there is little wind. While it is speculated that increased pressure inside of tree limbs may be the culprit, the exact cause of SBD is still mostly unknown. 

SBD occurs most frequently in black oaks around Yosemite. On hot days, avoid sitting or pitching a tent directly underneath black oak’s branches just in case a branch drop occurs. Do not leave immobile people, such as infants or the elderly, directly beneath branches either. If you hear a loud crack from overhead, quickly run away from the tree itself. Steering clear of already affected trees is also a great way to stay safe from this hazard and helps park operations act on and maintain tree health accordingly.

If you see a tree or branch fall, please report it to the nearest ranger or through our website.

node.accessibility_caption: Electrical lines hover over a river, with a granite mountain wall and green trees in the background.

node.text:
Power up! One year ago today, the #GreatAmericanOutdoorsAct (GAOA) was signed into law. With $11.8 million of funding provided through GAOA, the park will address critical electrical infrastructure, including the repair of high voltage transmission lines that serve multiple areas and provide power, lighting, and heating for a variety of structures within the park. Current transmission lines, and their supporting metal structures, were originally constructed in the mid-1930s. When finished, the project will bring the line to updated Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) and California Public Utilities Commission (CPUC) standards and decrease spending of park funds associated with ongoing repairs. 

#GAOA, #LWCF, #GreatAmericanOutdoorsAct

node.text:
Throughout human history, songs have served as a catalyst for connection. Songs have continuously been used to celebrate one’s culture, bring people together and bring about the emotions that only music can surface. While we may be surrounded by human song on our day-to-day basis, we may also encounter them through the natural world around us. 

As a Global Important Bird Area, Yosemite is enriched by birdsongs throughout the park. Although birdsongs may sound like beautiful melodies for us, they can be a means to defend and impress. Many birds are territorial, meaning that they lay claim to specific areas. Songs allow them to identify these regions as their own and are often used to defend this space. In other circumstances, male birds use songs to attract females. Melodies give these birds a chance to show off and impress potential mates. Being mindful of the distinctive soundscapes around us can help us differentiate and identify birds we encounter anywhere in the world. 

With 262 different species documented inside the park, there are endless opportunities to enjoy birding in Yosemite. Just a stroll through the park can introduce you to a whole new world of sound and flight right above your head. For more information on birds and birdwatching in Yosemite, please visit https://www.nps.gov/yose/planyourvisit/birdwatching.htm. 

[Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SbkqNiiwHXg]

node.accessibility_caption: A large waterfall visible in two distinct portions in the foreground, with a pink and blue sunset sky in the background.

node.text:
Hey….do you hear that? It sounds like someone turned the faucet back on!

If you’ve been around Yosemite Valley, you may have noticed that Yosemite Falls looks very different from just a few days ago. Thunderstorms over the past couple of days have brought life back to the waterfall, bringing with it an impressive increase in water flow that is typically not seen in late summer.

Yosemite Falls is an ephemeral waterfall, meaning it only flows seasonally, because it is primarily fed by snowmelt from higher elevations. As snow transforms into its liquid phase, water flows downstream, accumulating into Yosemite Creek. After a long journey in the high country, the creek eventually plummets into Yosemite Valley, creating the monumental waterfall. When heavy rainfall occurs at higher elevations, the already liquid water follows the same journey, traveling south toward the edge of the Valley. 

Rainstorms, with their torrential force, have the striking ability to revitalize a number of Yosemite’s waterfalls. Mirroring nature’s annual cycles, Yosemite Falls’ transitory existence is a fleeting gift throughout the spring and summer.

node.accessibility_caption: Stephen Mather stands behind a cornerstone. He is standing atop a wooden construction site. A crowd of men and women stand in the background.

node.text:
On this day in Yosemite History: The Ahwahnee cornerstone 

The Ahwahnee stands as a marvel of California architectural history. Declared as a National Historic Landmark in 1987, its creation was originally conceived by Stephen T. Mather, the first director of the National Park Service. Mather sought to draw in visitors to the newly established national parks in a way that combined the grandeur of nature with the extravagance of high-class lodging. 

On August 1, 1926, Mather laid down the first cornerstone of The Ahwahnee. Gilbert Underwood, the hotel’s ultimate architect, designed the hotel with wildfires in mind. To avoid this natural threat, the structure was primarily built with steel, granite, and concrete. Building exteriors were stained to resemble redwood, expanding on the aesthetic of the National Park Service rustic architectural style that had emerged earlier in the century within the park. The Ahwahnee challenged the way visitors could enjoy the newly established national parks at the time and symbolized a new forefront in the recently developed rustic style. The hotel officially opened on July 16, 1927, taking only eleven months to construct. 

Just as Yosemite’s graceful granite cliffs inspired these early architects, these same walls continue to influence the park’s everyday management.  Today, the hotel stands as a stark reminder of the innovative structures brought about by Yosemite’s earliest administration, linking together the natural beauty of Yosemite’s landscape with the elegant design of human invention.

node.accessibility_caption: Half Dome being struck by a single bolt of lightning, seen from Cook's meadow. There are dark clouds overhead.

node.text:
As a flash flood watch remains in effect, be wary of another potential danger in the park: lightning! Although rescues regarding lightning are not too common, injuries and fatalities have happened. Given that there is no safe place outside during a storm, please make sure to follow these tips to avoid getting injured or killed by lightning: 

⚡️Do your research by checking the weather forecast and pay attention to local weather conditions. Dark fast-moving clouds, sudden increases in wind, drops in temperature, and thunder are all signs of oncoming weather. Learn about seasonal weather patterns in the area if you are planning on recreating in the park. 

⚡️Be willing to turn around at any time. When out hiking or climbing, be ready to turn around at the first sound of thunder. Try to descend from exposed summits, mountains, high ridges, and open granite slabs to lower terrain as quickly as you can. 

⚡️If you are outside, seek shelter! Do not position yourself next to tall solitary trees or metal trail signs. Avoid taking shelter under or against exposed, overhanging rocks. If possible, get inside of a building or vehicle whenever you hear thunder. 

⚡️Remember to always pack an extra layer of clothing and a raincoat whenever you go out even if rain isn't in the forecast.

node.text:
Here’s the situation: you are hanging out at your campsite or on a picnic area beach in Yosemite, when you hear a branch crack behind you. You turn around to find a bear approaching. What do you do?

You stand up, face the bear, wave your arms, and yell at the bear. We mean YELL at the bear, as loudly as you possibly can. Be aggressive with your voice and body language. You’re not just making noise; you’re scaring a bear away! You have to mean it for it to work.

Here are some examples of things you can yell:

HEY BEAR!!

GO BEAR!!!

GET OUT OF HERE BEAR!!

Or even just: AHHHHHHHHHHHHHH BEAR!!!!!!!!!

One half-hearted yell may not be enough to scare a bear. So, keep yelling LOUDLY and AGGRESSIVELY until the bear leaves. Yell, clap your hands, wave your arms, hit a stick against a tree, get other people to help you yell! You can even throw small objects like pinecones or small pebbles at the bear to help scare it. (You’re trying to gently hit the bear with the pebble or pinecone—not injure it: Bears don’t like being touched.) Don’t chase the bear; just use your voice to scare it away.

Do you have time to snap a quick picture? No!

Do you have time to look around for a pot to bang or a whistle to blow? No! Use your voice! Your voice is your most effective tool to scare a bear away (and you don’t have to go looking for it... unless you’re really scared).

When a bear is around people, it could be only moments away from getting food, so you need to make it feel unwelcome immediately. Once a bear is eating food, it will be harder to scare away and much more likely to return in search of more food, ultimately getting itself into more trouble. We also want bears to be immediately afraid of people (as they naturally are), rather than assuming most people aren’t scary.

To learn more about bear safety and how to #KeepBearsWild, please refer to the link in our bio.
